The European Council indicated on Thursday night that it had among others i) approved the Strasbourg agreement (the joint statement supplementing the political declaration agreed on March 11 by the European Commission and UK PM May), ii) agreed to an extension until Wed 22 May of the 29 March deadline provided that the Withdrawal Agreement is approved by the House of Commons next week, iii) but that if the Withdrawal Agreement is not approved next week, to an extension only until Fri 12 April, and expects the UK to “indicate a way forward before this date for consideration by the European Council”, iv) that the Withdrawal Agreement cannot be reopened, and that any unilateral commitment, statement or other act should be compatible with the letter and the spirit of the Withdrawal Agreement. EU Council President Donald Tusk indicated during the press conference that there are essentially four options on the table, 1) Theresa
May’s deal, 2) No deal, 3) A long extension, and 4) Revoking Article 50, the last
two of which would require the UK to hold European parliamentary elections. PM May, when quizzed repeatedly during her press conference, dismissed calls to revoke Article 50 as a viable option, reiterating that her government has no intention of taking part in the European Parliamentary elections, saying “it would be “wrong to ask voters to participate three years after voting to leave”, but acknowledged that she would need to work with Parliament if her deal failed.

Excel Developer @daz: there is a lot of disconnect around. at least germany's bond market gets in … Bund 10s dipped below 0% for first time since Oct 2016.

BE11:10am

Down to the next level of hell, I imagine. Though this take on Dante already has more levels than The Shard.

BE11:10am

On Monday, the House of Commons will likely vote on
Amendment a) tabled by MPs Letwin, Grieve and Benn to section 13 of the EU Withdrawal Act 2018 to create space in the Parliamentary timetable on Wednesday 27 March for indicative votes on the best way forward. Given the closeness of the vote when first proposed, (302 for versus 304 against), we think that this amendment is likely to pass.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Okay Citi. Analyse please, because god knows what we need here is more analysis.

BE11:11am

The European Council did not want to force a no-deal Brexit on Fri 29 March, so gave the UK more time to decide the best course of action. We continue to think that May’s deal is likely to be rejected by Parliament next week, on the basis that the government holds the third meaningful vote by Friday 28 March (to be compliant with the EU Council conclusion of a vote taking place next week). To be sure, we doubt that the maths have changed meaningfully for PM May to win at the third attempt, although the prospect of some majority for something other than her deal during the indicative votes could mobilise leavers and therefore make the final vote on her deal a closer affair. On balance, however, we think that many MPs may vote against the current deal, as the prospect of a No-Deal Brexit will likely encourage hard core Brexiteers, while the prospect of a longer extension for another future relationship without some of PM May’s red lines will likely encourage Remainers. The likelihood of a no confidence vote against the PM if her deal is rejected is rising, as is that of a snap election, and perhaps the end of May’s premiership, provided that a long extension is agreed by 12 April. However, the process towards a longer extension seems fraught with procedural risk. Indeed, it is not clear who would make the request and bring forward the necessary (secondary) legislation that Parliament would have to approve. We anticipate days, weeks and perhaps months of Brexit and political tensions. In this context, economic uncertainty is unlikely to recede

BE11:30am

The announcement of the intention to pursue a demerger of Smiths Medical and separately list the business in the UK is, in our view, a positive. We see a separation and listing as likely to create greater value for shareholders than the alternative of an IPO as well as providing clarity and a timeline for investors. Additionally, we see the opportunities and potential for separated and focused industrial and medical assets as greater than in the combined entity. Management has not identified any roadblocks to completion of this process and completion is expected in the first half of CY20. Furthermore we see optionality for shareholders with management committing to evaluating all opportunities to maximise value creation as the process moves forward.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Smiths Group‘s H1’19 results were 3% ahead of our EBITA forecast and management reaffirmed the outlook for FY19. There are puts and takes at a divisional level but the H1 confirmed solid underlying trends which should support a stronger H2 and our FY19/FY20 EBITA
forecasts are unchanged. [...] The combination of continued underlying progress and the potential value creation from the separation keeps our rating at Overweight with a December 2019 Price Target of 1,660p.

BE11:31am

Stifel also buying.

BE11:31am

Smiths' 1H results are slightly ahead of our expectations (headline operating profit of £246m vs our
forecast of £241m), and the group has confirmed that it will seek a full demerger of Medical. The
demerger will result in two UK listed companies, and is expected to compete during 1H20 (we believe
that the group is hoping to get this done within 12 months). For once, Smiths has delivered against
guidance and expectations and it has also reiterated its full-year outlook. At the divisional level, 1H
performance is mixed as expected, with strength in John Crane, Flex-Tek and Interconnect offset
by weaker Medical trends (which had been well flagged), and project timing issues at Detection (an
inventory build at group level in 1H is largely a function of this division readying for large deliveries
through 2H). Both Medical and Detection are expected to return to growth in 2H. The only division
which was notably different from our forecast was Interconnect, which was better than expected,
although some of this also appears to relate to project timing. In all, solid operational progress and
a very welcome conclusion on Medical: we continue to believe that this demerger should unlock
significant value. Reiterate Buy, 1,800p target price.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

And Sandy Morris at Jefferies, who thankfully continues to write for humans rather than machines.

cracklenpop @excel Negative yield on 10-yr bunds = investors now more concerned about return of their capital rather than return on it
BE11:33am

Over 30 years one visited perhaps 10 Medical facilities and was generally impressed. One learned a huge amount. One remained, however, a layman. Sure, we could take issue with the results or the lack of organic revenue growth, and even bemoan the periodic hiccups like European product registration, the exit from insulin pumps, and accrual of rebates to distributors. What we could not do was to press management on Medical's relative performance, product by product, against a market and competitive backdrop that changed hugely. We believe Medical faced greater change than Aerospace, sold to GE in 2007. Medical remained, despite at least three attempts to sell it. Finally, Medical will depart. If criticism can be constructive, if more pointed and informed questioning can keep Medical on its toes, and unable to hide, so to speak, within a larger Group, Medical is more likely to thrive, in our view.

FATDAZ @cracklenop yep
BE11:34am

He's on hold with a £18 target, but this working is a journey.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

1H18 Group sales and EBIT would be 27% and 29% lower respectively without Medical. Its separation will mark meaningful change. In isolation, we believe John Crane would command a higher PER multiple than Smiths Group does. Flex-Tek should do so too, in our view, but that is less certain. Given the growth in defence spending, we believe Interconnect should trade at least in line with the Group. Detection is more of an imponderable. We sense there is a natural affinity for Detection by sell-side and buyside, but we think it still has to prove itself and that the volatility in its sales may be an enduring distraction; a scab to periodically pick at. Then there is Medical, a business that when separated could, even should, command a higher PER than Smiths Group. Please place your meaningful vote.

Here's Citi's "More to Go For: 30%+ Bull Case to end-2020" recap.

BE11:42am

Our analysis at the start of 2019 highlighted a strong enhanced buy signal for European equities when overlaying Citi US Equity Strategist Tobias Levkovich’s Panic/Euphoria model for US equity sentiment with Citi’s Euro Area Economic Surprise Index (CESI). The median 12-month European equity return, when both indicators were at depressed levels, has been +27% with a win ratio of 98%. There have been 46 weeks when the enhanced twin signal has been activated during four
separate time periods (2005, late 2008, 2011, 2012) in the last 15 years. Both
indicators were depressed for six weeks from mid-December 2018 to mid-January this year. European equities have rallied hard YTD with total returns approaching 15%, but with record outflows from the region there has been little investor participation. Our “Don’t Panic” median pathway suggests there are further gains ahead in the coming 6-9 months, which supports our end-2019 Stoxx target of 400.

LegalEagle @Tom Dalgeish seems to be start up - I think its the trend in a number of jurisdictions

BE11:43am

Investors remain unconvinced due to concerns over politics and the cycle’s longevity. But, we see the
case for 2019-20 upside equity risk. UK and European equities appear attractively valued: median DYs for both are c10% above a post-1985 average, 5-6% market FCF yields, historic equity/bond yield gaps.

Excel Developer @BE: The point is, do lower bond yields signal recession, and a crash in equities. Bonds in themselves are quite boring, admittedly the excitement is in equities. It's just bond market can gives a preview/precursor as to equity price action.

Dividends are a key battleground. Bears need dividends not to be paid. Bulls need them to be paid.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

surplus FCF in all sectors bar Utilities, low [median] net debt/EBITDA and even some [limited] payout flex. Even applying a small discount to current expected 2019-20 DPS growth expectations, European equities would return 30%+ between now and end-2020 if share prices close the gap to underlying dividends. This would need European equities to re-rate from a current DY of 3.7% to 3.4% only. We see this as a plausible outcome and a risk to how most investors are currently positioned.

BE11:46am

We’ve outlined three key phases in 2019-20 in support of our bull case: 1) 1Q19 = battle between EPS downgrades and Brexit and US/China trade, 2) 2Q-3Q19 = China pivot or DonXi Put, given the role of the US via both the Fed and trade, ie does the pace of China slowdown slow or not, and 3) USD World = we’ve transitioned from a QEWorld to a USD-World where a weaker USD is likely to drive a return to synchronised global growth (anyone agree?) and risk on equity performance vs a strong USD with the opposite. Since the end of 2018, we have backed “nonnegative” outcomes to both Brexit and US/China discussions. There appears to be much greater “incentive alignment” than 6-12 months ago between the US and China, while Brexit looks likely to roll, albeit with ongoing high-level uncertainty. There are mixed signals from China data, but evidence of greenshoots within that, eg latest infrastructure contractor orders. On the USD, which we see as key, Citi’s Head of Macro Strategy Jeremy Hale backs a USD bear market

It's a business that deserves a certain level of scrutiny, both from the regulator and the media. Anyway, Caz put out a primer a few weeks ago with regards the FCA's concerns ....

BE11:54am

Amigo currently receives around 10% of the number of loan repayments from guarantors, which management have indicated has not increased materially for the Amigo business. Amigo maintains a robust process of checking affordability of loans for guarantors, as well as communicating the obligation of the guarantor if the primary borrower is unable to pay. We would highlight
that the FCA has in the past conducted a detailed review into the Amigo business before giving Amigo a full
authorization license. The FCA intends to publish their conclusions after January 2021, which we believe is
encouraging given any material concerns for the guarantor loan sector may have been addressed more swiftly by the regulator.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

At the origination of a loan an Amigo agent has a
phone conversation with certain borrowers, and all guarantors, to verify affordability and an understanding of
the terms of the loan, which we believe should reassure in relation to some of the FCA’s concerns regarding
guarantors’ understanding of their obligations.
